## Asia and
Oceania[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Asia and Oceania")]

### Australia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Australia")]

See also: [Medical education in
Australia](/wiki/Medical_education_in_Australia "Medical education in
Australia")

Historically, [Australian medical
schools](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_Australia "List of medical schools
in Australia") have followed the British tradition by conferring the degrees
of [Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of
Surgery](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Medicine_and_Bachelor_of_Surgery "Bachelor of
Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery") (MBBS) to its graduates whilst reserving
the title of Doctor of Medicine (MD) for their research training degree,
analogous to the [PhD](/wiki/PhD "PhD"), or for their [honorary
doctorates](/wiki/Honorary_doctorates "Honorary doctorates"). Although the
majority of Australian MBBS degrees have been graduate programs since the
1990s, under the previous [Australian Qualifications
Framework](/wiki/Australian_Qualifications_Framework "Australian
Qualifications Framework") (AQF) they remained categorised as Level 7 Bachelor
degrees together with other undergraduate programs.

The latest version of the AQF includes the new category of Level 9 Master's
(Extended) degrees which permits the use of the term 'Doctor' in the styling
of the degree title of relevant professional programs. As a result, various
Australian medical schools have replaced their MBBS degrees with the MD to
resolve the previous anomalous nomenclature.[25] With the introduction of the
Master's level MD, universities have also renamed their previous medical
research doctorates. The [University of
Melbourne](/wiki/University_of_Melbourne "University of Melbourne") was the
first to introduce the MD in 2011 as a basic medical degree, and has renamed
its research degree to Doctor of Medical Science (DMedSc).[26]

### Bangladesh[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Bangladesh")]

See also: [List of medical colleges in
Bangladesh](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools#Bangladesh "List of medical
schools")

In [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh"), admission to medical colleges
is organized by the Governing Body of [University of
Dhaka](/wiki/University_of_Dhaka "University of Dhaka"). A single admission
test is held for government and private colleges. Due to the highly
competitive nature of these exams, the total number of applicants across the
country is around 78 times the number of students accepted.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Admission is based on the entrance examination, as well as students'
individual academic records.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The entrance examination consists carries a time limit of one hour. 100 marks
are allocated based on objective questions, in which the mark allocation is
distributed between a variety of subjects. Biology questions carry 30 marks,
Chemistry carries 25, Physics carries 20, English carries 15, and general
knowledge carries 10.

Additionally, students' previous SSC (Secondary School Certificate) and HSC
(Higher Secondary School Certificate) scores each carry up to 100 marks
towards the overall examination result.

English students prepare themselves for the admission exam ahead of time. This
is because as the [GCSE](/wiki/GCSE "GCSE") and [A-Level](/wiki/A-Level
"A-Level") exams do not cover parts of the Bangladesh syllabus.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The undergraduate program consists of five years study, followed by a one-year
internship. The degrees granted are Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of
Surgery ([M.B.B.S.](/wiki/Bachelors_of_Medicine_and_Surgery "Bachelors of
Medicine and Surgery")). Further postgraduate qualifications may be obtained
in the form of Diplomas or Degrees (MS or MD),
[M.Phil](/wiki/Master_of_Philosophy "Master of Philosophy") and FCPS
(Fellowship of the College of Physicians and Surgeons).

The [University of Dhaka](/wiki/University_of_Dhaka "University of Dhaka")
launched[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] a new BSc in "Radiology and
Imaging Technology," offering 30 students the opportunity to contribute
towards their entrance exam grade. For students who have passed the HSC, this
course contributes towards 25% of the mark. The course contributes up to 75%
for Diploma-holding students. The duration of the course is four years (plus
12 weeks for project submission). The course covers a variety of topics,
including behavioural science, radiological ethics, imaging physics and
general procedure.

### Cambodia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Cambodia")]

After 6 years of general medical education (a foundation year + 5 years), all
students will graduate with **Bachelor of Medical Sciences (BMedSc)**
**បរិញ្ញាប័ត្រ វិទ្យាសាស្រ្តវេជ្ជសាស្ត្រ**. This degree does not allow
graduates to work independently as Physician, but it is possible for those who
wish to continue to master's degrees in other fields relating to medical
sciences such as Public Health, Epidemiology, Biomedical Science, Nutrition...

Medical graduates, who wish to be fully qualified as physicians or specialists
must follow the rule as below:

  * General Practitioner's (GP) course is of 8 years (BMedSc + 2-year internship). Clinical rotation in the internship is modulated within 4 main disciplines (general medicine, surgery, gynecology, pediatrics).The medical degree awarded is **Doctor of Medicine (MD)** **សញ្ញាប័ត្រ វេជ្ជបណ្ឌិត** (equivalent to master's degree).
  * After graduating with BMedSc; any students, who wishes to enter Resodency Training Programs, are required to sit for a rigorous and Entrance Exam. The duration of residency programs lasts from 3 to 4 years after BMedSc (BMedSc + 3– 4 years of specialization). Once the graduates, after successfully defense their practicum thesis, are officially awarded **the Degree of Specialized Doctor (MD-with specialization)** **សញ្ញាប័ត្រវេជ្ជបណ្ឌិតឯកទេស** "Professional Doctorate".

All Medical graduates must complete **Thesis Defense** and pass the **National
Exit Exam** **ប្រឡងចេញថ្នាក់ជាតិក្នុងវិស័យសុខាភិបាល** to become either GPs or
Medical or Surgical Specialists.

### Hong Kong[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Hong Kong")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/The_University_of_Hong_Kong_Li_Ka_Shing_Faculty_of_Medicine_1.jpg/200px-
The_University_of_Hong_Kong_Li_Ka_Shing_Faculty_of_Medicine_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_University_of_Hong_Kong_Li_Ka_Shing_Faculty_of_Medicine_1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_University_of_Hong_Kong_Li_Ka_Shing_Faculty_of_Medicine_1.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Li Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine](/wiki/Li_Ka_Shing_Faculty_of_Medicine "Li Ka
Shing Faculty of Medicine") held by [HKU](/wiki/HKU "HKU") is among the oldest
western medicine schools in [Far East](/wiki/Far_East "Far East").

Main article: [Medical education in Hong
Kong](/wiki/Medical_education_in_Hong_Kong "Medical education in Hong Kong")

Hong Kong has only two comprehensive medical faculties, the [Li Ka Shing
Faculty of Medicine, University of Hong
Kong](/wiki/Li_Ka_Shing_Faculty_of_Medicine,_University_of_Hong_Kong "Li Ka
Shing Faculty of Medicine, University of Hong Kong") and the [Faculty of
Medicine, Chinese University of Hong
Kong](/wiki/Faculty_of_Medicine,_Chinese_University_of_Hong_Kong "Faculty of
Medicine, Chinese University of Hong Kong"), and they are also the sole two
institutes offering medical and pharmacy programs. Other healthcare discipline
programs (like [nursing](/wiki/Nursing "Nursing")) are dispersed among some
other universities which do not host a medical faculty.

Prospective medical students enter either one of the two faculties of medicine
available (held by [The University of Hong
Kong](/wiki/Li_Ka_Shing_Faculty_of_Medicine "Li Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine")
and [The Chinese University of Hong Kong](/wiki/CUHK_Medical_School "CUHK
Medical School")) from high schools. The medical program consists of 5 years
for those who take the traditional Hong Kong's Advanced Level Examination
([HKALE](/wiki/HKALE "HKALE")) for admission, or 6 years for those who take
the new syllabus Hong Kong's Diploma of Secondary School Education Examination
([HKDSE](/wiki/HKDSE "HKDSE")). International students who take examinations
other the two mentioned will be assessed by the schools to decide if they will
take the 5-year program or the 6-year one.

The competition of entering the medical undergraduate programs is cut-throat
as the number of intake each year is very limited with a quota of 210 from
each school (420 in total) and candidates need to attain an excellent
examination result and good performance in interview. The schools put a great
emphasis on students' languages (both [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language
"Chinese language") and [English](/wiki/English_language "English language"))
and communication skills as they need to communicate with other health care
professionals and patients or their family in the future.

During their studies at the medical schools, students need to accumulate
enough clinical practicing hours in addition before their graduation.

The education leads to a degree of _Bachelor of medicine and Bachelor of
surgery_ (M.B., B.S. by [HKU](/wiki/HKU "HKU") or M.B., Ch.B. by
[CUHK](/wiki/CUHK "CUHK")). After a 5- or 6-year degree, one year of
internship follows in order to be eligible to practice in Hong Kong.

Both HKU and CUHK provide a prestigious bachelor of pharmacy course that is
popular among local and overseas students. Students of most other health care
disciplines have a study duration of 4 years, except [nursing](/wiki/Nursing
"Nursing") programs which require 5 years.

### India[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: India")]

Main article: [Medical college in India](/wiki/Medical_college_in_India
"Medical college in India")

See also: [List of medical Colleges in
India](/wiki/List_of_medical_colleges_in_India "List of medical colleges in
India")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Tirunelveli_Medical_College2.JPG/220px-
Tirunelveli_Medical_College2.JPG)](/wiki/File:Tirunelveli_Medical_College2.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Tirunelveli_Medical_College2.JPG "Enlarge")

Tirunelveli Medical College, Tamil Nadu, India

In [India](/wiki/India "India"), admission to medical colleges is organized
both by the central government
[CBSE](/wiki/Central_Board_of_Secondary_Education "Central Board of Secondary
Education") as well as the state governments through tests known as [entrance
examination](/wiki/Entrance_examination "Entrance examination"). Students who
have successfully completed their 10+2 (Physics, Chemistry and Biology Marks
are considered and PCB is mandatory) education (higher secondary school) can
appear for the tests the same year.

The All-India Pre Medical/Dental Test for filling up of 15% of total
[MBBS](/wiki/MBBS "MBBS") seats in [India](/wiki/India "India"), conducted by
[CBSE](/wiki/Central_Board_of_Secondary_Education "Central Board of Secondary
Education") (Central Board for Secondary Education) in the month of April/May
intakes about only 2,500 students out of a total applicants of over
600,000.[27] The [Supreme Court Of India](/wiki/Supreme_Court_Of_India
"Supreme Court Of India") has mandated the necessity of [entrance
examination](/wiki/Entrance_examination "Entrance examination") based upon
multiple choice questions and negative marking for wrong answers with
subsequent merit over 50% for selection into MBBS as well as higher medical
education. The entrance exams are highly [competitive](/wiki/Competitive
"Competitive").

The graduate program consists of three professionals consisting of 9
semesters, followed by one-year internship (rotating housemanship). The degree
granted is Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery
([M.B.B.S.](/wiki/Bachelors_of_Medicine_and_Surgery "Bachelors of Medicine and
Surgery")) of five years and six months.

The graduate degree of MBBS is divided into 3 professionals, with each
professional ending with a professional exam conducted by the
[university](/wiki/University "University") (a single university may have up
to dozens of medical colleges offering various graduate/post-graduate/[post-
doctoral](/wiki/Post-doctoral "Post-doctoral") degrees). After clearing this
the student moves into the next professional. Each professional exam consists
of a theory exam and a practical exam conducted not only by the same college
but also external examiners. The exams are tough and many students are unable
to clear them, thereby prolonging their degree time. The first professional is
for 1 year and includes preclinical subjects, anatomy, physiology and
biochemistry. The second professional is for 1 and a half year and has
subjects pathology, pharmacology, microbiology (including immunology) and
forensic medicine. Clinical exposure starts in the second professional. The
third professional is divided into two parts. Part 1 consists of
ophthalmology, [ENT](/wiki/Otorhinolaryngology "Otorhinolaryngology"), and PSM
([preventive and social medicine](/wiki/Preventive_care "Preventive care"))
and part 2 consists of general-medicine[including dermatology, psychiatry as
short subjects], general surgery [including radiology, anaesthesiology and
orthopaedics as short subjects] and pediatrics and gynaecology and obstetrics
. This is followed by one-year of compulsory [internship](/wiki/Internship
"Internship") (rotatory [house-
surgeonship](/wiki/House_officer_\(disambiguation\) "House officer
\(disambiguation\)")). After internship, the degree of MBBS is awarded by the
respective university. Some states have made rural service compulsory for a
certain period of time after MBBS.

Selection for higher medical education is through [entrance
examinations](/wiki/Entrance_examination "Entrance examination") as mandated
by the [Supreme Court Of India](/wiki/Supreme_Court_Of_India "Supreme Court Of
India"). Further postgraduate qualifications may be obtained as [Post-
graduate](/wiki/Post-graduate "Post-graduate") [Diploma](/wiki/Diploma
"Diploma") of two years residency or [Doctoral](/wiki/Doctoral "Doctoral")
[Degree](/wiki/Academic_degree "Academic degree")
([MS](/wiki/Master_of_Surgery "Master of Surgery"): Master of Surgery, or
[MD](/wiki/Doctor_of_Medicine "Doctor of Medicine")) of three years of
residency under the aegis of the Medical Council of India. 50% of all MD/MS
seats in India are filled up through "All-India Post-Graduate Medical Entrance
Examination conducted by [AIIMS](/wiki/AIIMS "AIIMS") (All-India Institute Of
Medical Sciences) under the supervision of the Directorate General Of Health
Services. Theses/Dissertations are mandatory to be submitted and cleared by
university along with examinations(written and clinicals) to obtain MD/MS
degree. Further sub-speciality [post-doctoral](/wiki/Post-doctoral "Post-
doctoral") qualification (DM - [Doctorate of
Medicine](/wiki/Doctorate_of_Medicine "Doctorate of Medicine"), or
[MCh](/wiki/MCh "MCh") \- Magister of Chirurgery) of three years of residency
followed by university examinations may also be obtained.[28]

PG (post-graduate) qualification is equivalent to M.D./M.S., consisting of
two/three-years residency after [MBBS](/wiki/MBBS "MBBS"). A PG diploma may
also be obtained through the National Board of Examinations (NBE), which also
offers three-years residency for sub-specialisation. All degrees by NBE are
called DNB ([Diplomate of National Board](/wiki/Diplomate_of_National_Board
"Diplomate of National Board")). DNB's are awarded only after clearance of
theses/dissertations and examinations. DNBs equivalent to DM/MCh have to clear
examinations mandatorily.[29]

### Indonesia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Indonesia")]

See also: [List of medical schools in
Indonesia](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_Indonesia "List of medical schools
in Indonesia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Medstudentindonesia.jpg/220px-
Medstudentindonesia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Medstudentindonesia.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Medstudentindonesia.jpg "Enlarge")

A group of Indonesian medical students of [Trisakti
University](/wiki/Trisakti_University "Trisakti University") trains with an
obstetric mannequin.

In [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia"), high school graduates who want to
enroll to public medical schools must have their names enlisted by their high
school faculty in the "SNMPTN Undangan" program, arranged by Directorate
General of Higher Education, Ministry of National Education. Depending on the
high school accreditation, only the class' top 10%-15% will be considered for
admissions. Fewer places are available through entrance exam conducted
autonomously by each university. These exams are highly competitive for
medicine, especially in prestigious institutions such as [University of
Indonesia](/wiki/University_of_Indonesia "University of Indonesia") in
Jakarta, [Airlangga University](/wiki/Airlangga_University "Airlangga
University") in Surabaya, and [Gadjah Mada
University](/wiki/Gadjah_Mada_University "Gadjah Mada University") in
Yogyakarta. For private medical school, almost all places are offered through
independently run admission tests.

The standard Indonesian medical school curriculum is six years long. The four
years undergraduate program is composed mainly of classroom education,
continued with the last two years in professional program primarily includes
rotations in clinical settings where students learn patient care firsthand. If
they pass undergraduate program they will have "S.Ked" (Bachelor of Medicine)
in their title and if they finished the professional program and pass the
national examination arranged by IDI (Indonesian Medical Association) they
will become general physician and receive "dr. (doctor)".

Upon graduation, a physician planning to become a specialist in specific field
of medicine must complete a [residency](/wiki/Residency_\(medicine\)
"Residency \(medicine\)"), which is a supervised training with period of three
to four years. A physician who sub-specializes or who desires more supervised
experience may complete a [fellowship](/wiki/Fellowship_\(medicine\)
"Fellowship \(medicine\)"), which is an additional one to three years of
supervised training in his/her area of expertise

### Iran[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Iran")]

See also: [List of medical schools in
Iran](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_the_Middle_East#iran "List of medical
schools in the Middle East")

General medicine education in Iran takes 7 to 7.5 years. Students enter the
university after high school. Students study basic medical science (such as
anatomy, physiology, biochemistry, histology, biophysics, embryology, etc.)
for 2.5 years. At the end of this period they should pass a "basic science"
exam. Those who passed the exam will move on to study physiopathology of
different organs in the next 1.5 years. The organ-based learning approach
emphasizes critical thinking and clinical application. In the next period of
education students enter clinics and educational hospitals for two years.
During this period, they will also learn practical skills such as history
taking and physical examination. Students should then pass the "pre-
internship" exam to enter the last 1.5 years of education in which medical
students function as interns. During this period, medical students participate
in all aspects of medical care of the patients and they take night calls. At
the end of these 7.5 years students are awarded an M.D degree. M.D doctors can
continue their educations through residency and fellowship.

### Israel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=34
"Edit section: Israel")]

See also: [List of medical schools in
Israel](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_the_Middle_East#Israel "List of
medical schools in the Middle East")

There are five university medical schools in Israel: the
[Technion](/wiki/Technion "Technion") in Haifa, [Ben Gurion
University](/wiki/Ben_Gurion_University "Ben Gurion University") in Be'er
Sheva, [Tel Aviv University](/wiki/Tel_Aviv_University "Tel Aviv University"),
the [Hebrew University](/wiki/Hebrew_University "Hebrew University") in
Jerusalem and the Medical school of the [Bar-Ilan University](/wiki/Bar-
Ilan_University "Bar-Ilan University") in [Ramat Gan](/wiki/Ramat_Gan "Ramat
Gan"). These all follow the European 6-year model except [Bar-Ilan
University](/wiki/Bar-Ilan_University "Bar-Ilan University") which has a four-
year program similar to the US system.[30]

The Technion Medical School, Ben Gurion University, and Tel Aviv University
Sackler Faculty of Medicine[31] offer 4-year MD programs for American
Bachelor's graduates who have taken the [MCAT](/wiki/MCAT "MCAT"), interested
in completing rigorous medical education in Israel before returning to the US
or Canada.

The entrance requirements of the various schools of medicine are very strict.
Israeli students require a [high school Baccalaureate](/wiki/Bagrut "Bagrut")
average above 100 and [psychometric
examination](/wiki/Psychometric_Entrance_Test "Psychometric Entrance Test")
grade over 700. The demand for medical education is strong and growing and
there is a lack of doctors in Israel.

The degree of Doctor of Medicine (MD) is legally considered to be equivalent
to a [Masters degree](/wiki/Masters_degree "Masters degree") within the
Israeli Educational System .[32]

### Japan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Japan")]

See also: [List of medical schools in
Japan](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_Japan "List of medical schools in
Japan")

In [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan"), medical schools are faculties of universities
and thus they are undergraduate programs that generally last for six years.
Admission is based on an exam taken at the end of high school and an entrance
exam at the university itself, which is the most competitive.

Medical students study Liberal Arts and Science for the first 1–2 years, which
include Physics, Mathematics, Chemistry, and Foreign Languages together with 2
years long Basic Medicine (Anatomy, Physiology, Pharmacology, Immunology),
Clinical Medicine, [Public health](/wiki/Public_health "Public health"), and
[Forensics](/wiki/Forensics "Forensics") for the next two years.

Medical students train in the University Hospital for the last two years.
Clinical training is a part of the curriculum. Upon completion of the
graduation examination, students are awarded an M.D. Medical graduates are
titled as Doctor, as are Ph.D. holders. The University does have an MD/PhD
program that enables Doctors of Medicine to become Ph.D. holders, as well.

At the end, Medical students take the National Medical License examination
and, if they pass it, become a Physician and register in the record in the
[Ministry of Health, Labour and
Welfare](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health,_Labour_and_Welfare "Ministry of Health,
Labour and Welfare"). The scope of this exam encompasses every aspect of
medicine.

### Jordan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=36
"Edit section: Jordan")]

The [Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Medicine_and_Surgery
"Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery") ([MBBS](/wiki/MBBS "MBBS")) degree is
awarded in [Jordan](/wiki/Jordan "Jordan") after completion of six years
comprising three years of [medical sciences](/wiki/Medical_sciences "Medical
sciences") and three [clinical](/wiki/Clinic "Clinic") years. Currently, four
[state supported universities](/wiki/Public_university "Public university")
include a medical school and grant the degree, which are:

  * [Jordan University of Science and Technology](/wiki/Jordan_University_of_Science_and_Technology "Jordan University of Science and Technology") in [Irbid](/wiki/Irbid "Irbid")
  * [University of Jordan](/wiki/University_of_Jordan "University of Jordan") in [Amman](/wiki/Amman "Amman")
  * [Mutah University](/wiki/Mutah_University "Mutah University") in [Al Karak](/wiki/Al_Karak "Al Karak")
  * [Hashemite University](/wiki/Hashemite_University "Hashemite University") in [Zarqa](/wiki/Zarqa "Zarqa")

Further information: [Medical education in
Jordan](/wiki/Medical_education_in_Jordan "Medical education in Jordan")

### Kyrgyzstan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=37
"Edit section: Kyrgyzstan")]

In Kyrgyzstan, the Government university Kyrgyz State Medical Academy offers 6
years duration undergraduate (bachelor's degree) program whereas the other
institutions mostly private such as the _International School of Medicine_ at
the **International University of Kyrgyzstan**[33][34] offers a five-year
medical program, with a requisite for English knowledge, that is recognized by
the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health
Organization"), the [General Medical Council](/wiki/General_Medical_Council
"General Medical Council"), and [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO"). The medical
school is also partnered with the [University of South Florida School of
Medicine](/wiki/University_of_South_Florida "University of South Florida"),
the [University of Heidelberg](/wiki/University_of_Heidelberg "University of
Heidelberg") (Germany), the Novosibirsk Medical University (Russia), and the
[University of Sharjah](/wiki/University_of_Sharjah "University of Sharjah")
(UAE).

Other medical schools located in Kyrgyzstan include the 5 years duration
MD/MBBS undergraduate degree program at [International University of Science
and Business or Mezhdunarodnyy Universitet Nauki i Biznesa,
Kyrgyzstan](/w/index.php?title=International_University_of_Science_and_Business_or_Mezhdunarodnyy_Universitet_Nauki_i_Biznesa,_Kyrgyzstan&action=edit&redlink=1
"International University of Science and Business or Mezhdunarodnyy
Universitet Nauki i Biznesa, Kyrgyzstan \(page does not exist\)")[35] others
are the [Asian Medical Institute,
Kyrgyzstan](/wiki/Asian_Medical_Institute,_Kyrgyzstan "Asian Medical
Institute, Kyrgyzstan")[36] and the [Medical Institute, Osh State
University](/wiki/Medical_Institute,_Osh_State_University "Medical Institute,
Osh State University")[37] and so on.

### Lebanon[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=38
"Edit section: Lebanon")]

In Lebanon, there are two programs of medical education followed: the American
system (4 years) and the European system (6 years). Programs are offered in
English and French. Admission requirements to the American system requires a
candidate to complete a bachelor's degree along with specific pre-medical
courses during the undergraduate years, and writing the MCAT examination.
European programs usually requires a candidate to complete 1 year of general
science followed by a selection exam by the end of the year.

Schools following the American system (M.D. degree) are:

  * [American University of Beirut](/wiki/American_University_of_Beirut "American University of Beirut"): located in [Beirut](/wiki/Beirut "Beirut") and is the oldest medical school in Lebanon. Training will take place at the American University of Beirut Medical center (AUBMC) in Beirut.
  * [Lebanese American University](/wiki/Lebanese_American_University "Lebanese American University") (LAU): LAU Medical school is located in [Byblos](/wiki/Byblos "Byblos") and has a 10-year affiliation with [Partners Harvard Medical International](/wiki/Partners_Harvard_Medical_International "Partners Harvard Medical International"). Training will take place at the University Medical center - Rizk Hospital (UMC-RH) located in [Beirut](/wiki/Beirut "Beirut"). It is also affiliated with Clemenceau Medical Center and [Rafik Hariri University Hospital](/wiki/Rafik_Hariri_University_Hospital "Rafik Hariri University Hospital").
  * [University of Balamand](/wiki/University_of_Balamand "University of Balamand"): located in [Koura](/wiki/Koura_District "Koura District"), north Lebanon. Training will take place at the Saint George University Medical center in Beirut.

The language of instruction in all three is English.

Schools following the European system (MBBS degree) are:

  * [Lebanese University](/wiki/Lebanese_University "Lebanese University"): languages of instruction are French and English. Training will take place at the [Rafik Hariri University Hospital](/wiki/Rafik_Hariri_University_Hospital "Rafik Hariri University Hospital") located in [Beirut](/wiki/Beirut "Beirut").
  * [Saint Joseph University](/wiki/Saint_Joseph_University "Saint Joseph University"): language of instruction is French. Training will take place in [Hôtel-Dieu de France](/wiki/H%C3%B4tel-Dieu_de_France "Hôtel-Dieu de France") hospital located in [Beirut](/wiki/Beirut "Beirut").
  * [Beirut Arab University](/wiki/Beirut_Arab_University "Beirut Arab University"): language of instruction is English. Training will take place at Hammoud Hospital UMC located in [Sidon](/wiki/Sidon "Sidon") and [Rafik Hariri University Hospital](/wiki/Rafik_Hariri_University_Hospital "Rafik Hariri University Hospital") located in [Beirut](/wiki/Beirut "Beirut").
  * [Holy Spirit University of Kaslik](/wiki/Holy_Spirit_University_of_Kaslik "Holy Spirit University of Kaslik"): Located in [Jounieh](/wiki/Jounieh "Jounieh"), languages of instruction are French and English. Training will take place at the [Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Notre Dame des Secours](/wiki/Centre_Hospitalier_Universitaire_Notre_Dame_des_Secours "Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Notre Dame des Secours") located in [Byblos](/wiki/Byblos "Byblos").

### Malaysia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=39
"Edit section: Malaysia")]

See also: [List of medical schools in
Malaysia](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_Malaysia "List of medical schools
in Malaysia")

In Malaysia, getting into medical school is regarded as difficult, due to high
fees and a rigorous selection process.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Some
new medical schools do offer a foundation in medicine course before admission
into a full-time medical programme. Most government, and some private medical
schools offer M.D., and others mostly offer MBBS degrees.

### Myanmar[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=40
"Edit section: Myanmar")]

See also: [List of medical schools in
Myanmar](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools#Myanmar "List of medical schools")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Panorama_view_of_Lanmadaw_campus.jpg/900px-
Panorama_view_of_Lanmadaw_campus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panorama_view_of_Lanmadaw_campus.jpg
"Panorama view of Lanmadaw Campus")

[](/wiki/File:Panorama_view_of_Lanmadaw_campus.jpg "File:Panorama view of
Lanmadaw campus.jpg")

Panorama view of Lanmadaw Campus

There are *five medical institutions - UM 1, UM 2, DSMA, UM Mdy, and UM Mgy -
in Myanmar.

  * (Now,there are six universities in total. UMTG,University of Medicine Taunggyi - launched since 2015)

  * edited by #mm_ymb

  
Myanmar medical schools are government-funded and require Myanmar citizenship
for eligibility. No private medical school exists at this moment. In
[Myanmar](/wiki/Myanmar "Myanmar"), admission to medical colleges is organized
under the Department of Health Science, which is the branch of Ministry of
Health of Myanmar.

  * (Now, we have been using as "Ministry of Health and Sport" and it is official usage) edited by #mm_ymb

A student can join one of the Five(*Now six) medical universities of Myanmar
if he gets the highest scores in the science combination of the matriculation
examination. This exam is highly competitive. Entrance is solely based on this
examination and academic records have very minor consequences on an
application. The undergraduate program is five years plus one year for work
experience in government hospitals. After medical school, Myanmar medical
graduates are under contract to spend one year of internship and three years
of tenure in rural areas before they are eligible for most residency
positions. The degree granted is Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery
([M.B.B.S.](/wiki/Bachelors_of_Medicine_and_Surgery "Bachelors of Medicine and
Surgery")). Further postgraduate qualifications may be obtained as a Degree
(M.Med. Sc) and (Dr.Med.Sc).

### New
Zealand[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=42 "Edit
section: New Zealand")]

See also: [List of medical schools in New
Zealand](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools#New_Zealand "List of medical schools")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Faculty_of_Medical_and_Health_Sciences%2C_University_of_Auckland.jpg/220px-
Faculty_of_Medical_and_Health_Sciences%2C_University_of_Auckland.jpg)](/wiki/File:Faculty_of_Medical_and_Health_Sciences,_University_of_Auckland.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Faculty_of_Medical_and_Health_Sciences,_University_of_Auckland.jpg
"Enlarge")

Auckland School of Medicine

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Uni_of_Otago_medical_school.jpg/220px-
Uni_of_Otago_medical_school.jpg)](/wiki/File:Uni_of_Otago_medical_school.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Uni_of_Otago_medical_school.jpg "Enlarge")

Otago School of Medicine

New Zealand medical programs are undergraduate-entry programs of six years
duration. Students are considered for acceptance only after a year of
undergraduate basic sciences or, as alternative, following the completion of a
bachelor's degree. There are two main medical schools in New Zealand: the
[University of
Auckland](/wiki/University_of_Auckland,_Faculty_of_Medical_and_Health_Sciences
"University of Auckland, Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences") and the
[University of Otago](/wiki/University_of_Otago_Dunedin_School_of_Medicine
"University of Otago Dunedin School of Medicine"). Each of these has
subsidiary medical schools such as Otago's [Wellington School of Medicine and
Health Sciences](/wiki/University_of_Otago_Wellington_School_of_Medicine
"University of Otago Wellington School of Medicine") and Auckland's [Waikato
Clinical
School](/wiki/University_of_Auckland,_Faculty_of_Medical_and_Health_Sciences#Waikato_Clinical_School
"University of Auckland, Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences")[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_].

The first year of the medical degree is the basic sciences year, which
comprises study in chemistry, biology, physics, and biochemistry as well as
population health and behavioural sciences. The following two years are spent
studying human organ systems and pathological processes in more detail as well
as professional and communication development. Toward the end of the third
year, students begin direct contact with patients in hospital settings.

The clinical years begin fully at the beginning of year 4, where students
rotate through various areas of general clinical medicine with rotation times
varying from between two and six weeks. Year 5 continues this pattern,
focusing more on specialized areas of medicine and surgery. Final medical
school exams (exit exams) are actually held at the end of year 5, which is
different from most other countries, where final exams are held near the very
end of the medical degree. Final exams must be passed before the student is
allowed to enter year 6[39].

The final year (Year 6) of medical school is known as the "Trainee Intern"
year, wherein a student is known as a "Trainee Intern" (commonly referred to
in the hospitals as a "T.I."). Trainee interns repeat most rotations
undertaken in years 4 and 5 but at a higher level of involvement and
responsibility for patient care[40]. Trainee interns receive a stipend grant
from the New Zealand government (not applicable for international students).
At the current time, this is $NZ 26,756/year (about $US 18,500)[41]. Trainee
interns have responsibility under supervision for the care of about one-third
the patient workload of a junior doctor. However, all prescriptions and most
other orders (e.g., radiology requests and charting of IV fluids) made by
trainee interns must be countersigned by a registered doctor.

New Zealand medical schools currently award the degrees of [Bachelor of
Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Medicine "Bachelor of
Medicine") (MBChB)[42].

Upon completion of the 6th year, students go on to become "House Officers,"
also known as "House Surgeons" for 1–2 years where they rotate through
specialities in the first year and then begin to narrow down to what they'd
like to do for speciality training in the second year. After 2 years of house
officer work they apply to get into a training scheme and start to train
towards the speciality[43].

### Pakistan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=43
"Edit section: Pakistan")]

Main article: [Medical school in Pakistan](/wiki/Medical_school_in_Pakistan
"Medical school in Pakistan")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/%27Pakistan%27-KE_Med_Univ-
Sep_2016_%288%29.jpg/220px-%27Pakistan%27-KE_Med_Univ-
Sep_2016_%288%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%27Pakistan%27-KE_Med_Univ-
Sep_2016_\(8\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:%27Pakistan%27-KE_Med_Univ-Sep_2016_\(8\).jpg "Enlarge")

[King Edward Medical University](/wiki/King_Edward_Medical_University "King
Edward Medical University"), fourth oldest medical school in South Asia

In [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") a medical school is more often
referred to as a medical college. A medical college is affiliated with a
university as a department. There are however several medical universities and
medical institutes with their own medical colleges. All medical colleges and
universities are regulated by the respective provincial department of health.
They however have to be recognized after meeting a set criteria by a central
regulatory authority called [Pakistan Medical and Dental
Council](/wiki/Pakistan_Medical_and_Dental_Council "Pakistan Medical and
Dental Council") (PMDC) in [Islamabad](/wiki/Islamabad "Islamabad"). There are
almost equal number of government and private medical colleges and
universities, with their number exceeding 50. Admission to a government
medical college is highly competitive. Entrance into the medical colleges is
based on merit under the guidelines of PMDC. Both the academic performance at
the college (high school, grades 11-12) level and an entrance test like MCAT
are taken into consideration for the eligibility to enter most of the medical
colleges. After successfully completing five years of academic and clinical
training in the medical college and affiliated teaching hospitals the
graduates are awarded a [Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of
Surgery](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Medicine_and_Bachelor_of_Surgery "Bachelor of
Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery") ([MBBS](/wiki/MBBS "MBBS")) degree. The
graduates are then eligible to apply for a medical license from the PMDC. A
house job of one-year duration is mandatory in a teaching hospital after
completing five years of academic and clinical training in the medical
college.

### People's Republic of
China[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=44 "Edit
section: People's Republic of China")]

See also: [List of medical schools in the People's Republic of
China](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China "List
of medical schools in the People's Republic of China")

Medical education is normally a five-year [Bachelor
degree](/wiki/Bachelor_degree "Bachelor degree"), including one-year
internship (or clinical rotation, during which students are actively involved
in patient care) before the final degree is awarded. Clinical specialization
usually involves a two- or three-year [Master degree](/wiki/Master_degree
"Master degree"). Acceptance is based on the national entrance examination
used for all universities. There are a few colleges that teach in English and
accept foreign medical students. Some of those universities have increased
their course duration to 6 years.

The degree conferred is known as Bachelor of Clinical Medicine (BCM).

###
Philippines[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=45
"Edit section: Philippines")]

Main articles: [List of medical schools in the
Philippines](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_the_Philippines "List of medical
schools in the Philippines") and [Medical education in the
Philippines](/wiki/Medical_education_in_the_Philippines "Medical education in
the Philippines")

The Dominicans, under the Spanish Government, established the oldest medical
school in the Philippines in 1871, known as the [Faculty of Medicine and
Surgery](/wiki/University_of_Santo_Tomas_Faculty_of_Medicine_and_Surgery
"University of Santo Tomas Faculty of Medicine and Surgery") (at that time was
one with the [University of Santo Tomas Faculty of
Pharmacy](/wiki/University_of_Santo_Tomas_Faculty_of_Pharmacy "University of
Santo Tomas Faculty of Pharmacy"), also considered the oldest pharmacy school
in the Philippines) of the [Pontifical and Royal University of Santo
Tomas](/wiki/Pontifical_and_Royal_University_of_Santo_Tomas "Pontifical and
Royal University of Santo Tomas") in Intramuros, Manila.

Medical education in the Philippines became widespread under the
[American](/wiki/United_States "United States") administration. The Americans,
led by the insular government's Secretary of the Interior, [Dean
Worcester](/wiki/Dean_Worcester "Dean Worcester"), built the [University of
the Philippines College of
Medicine](/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines_College_of_Medicine "University
of the Philippines College of Medicine") and Surgery in 1905. By 1909, nursing
instruction was also begun at the Philippine Normal School.

At present there are a number of medical schools in the Philippines, notable
examples include the [University of the Philippines College of
Medicine](/wiki/University_of_the_Philippines_College_of_Medicine "University
of the Philippines College of Medicine"), [Our Lady of Fatima
University](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Fatima_University "Our Lady of Fatima
University"), [Far Eastern University – Nicanor Reyes Medical
Foundation](/wiki/Far_Eastern_University_%E2%80%93_Nicanor_Reyes_Medical_Foundation
"Far Eastern University – Nicanor Reyes Medical Foundation"), [Saint Louis
University International School of
Medicine](/wiki/Saint_Louis_University_International_School_of_Medicine "Saint
Louis University International School of Medicine"), [De La Salle Health
Sciences Institute](/wiki/De_La_Salle_Health_Sciences_Institute "De La Salle
Health Sciences Institute"), [University of Santo Tomas Faculty of Medicine
and Surgery](/wiki/University_of_Santo_Tomas_Faculty_of_Medicine_and_Surgery
"University of Santo Tomas Faculty of Medicine and Surgery"), [Pamantasan ng

Medicine](/w/index.php?title=Xavier_University_%E2%80%93_Ateneo_de_Cagayan,_Dr._Jose_P._Rizal_School_of_Medicine&action=edit&redlink=1
"Xavier University – Ateneo de Cagayan, Dr. Jose P. Rizal School of Medicine
\(page does not exist\)") in Cagayan de Oro, Ago medical educational center
AMEC-BCCM in Legazpi, Bicol and [University of Northern
Philippines](/wiki/University_of_Northern_Philippines "University of Northern
Philippines") in Vigan.

In 2007, the [Ateneo School of Medicine and Public
Health](/wiki/Ateneo_School_of_Medicine_and_Public_Health "Ateneo School of
Medicine and Public Health") was established. It is the first medical school
in the country to offer a [double degree](/wiki/Double_degree "Double degree")
program leading to the degrees [Doctor of Medicine](/wiki/Doctor_of_Medicine
"Doctor of Medicine") and Masters in Business Administration.

Any college graduate may apply for medical school given that they satisfy the
requirements set by the institutions. There is also a test known as the
[National Medical Admission
Test](/wiki/National_Medical_Admission_Test_\(Philippines\) "National Medical
Admission Test \(Philippines\)") or NMAT. Scores are given on a percentile
basis and a high ranking is a must to enter the top medical schools in the
country.

In most institutions, medical education lasts for four years. Basic subjects
are taken up in the first and second years, while clinical sciences are
studied in the second and third years. In their fourth year, students rotate
in the various hospital departments, spending up to two months each in the
fields of internal medicine, surgery, obstetrics and gynecology, and
pediatrics, and several weeks in the other specialties. After this, students
graduate with a Doctorate in Medicine and apply for postgraduate internship
(PGI) in an accredited hospital of their choice. After PGI, the student is
eligible to take the Medical Licensure Examination. Passing the examinations
confers the right to practice medicine as well as to apply in a Residency
Training Program.

### Republic of China
(Taiwan)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=46 "Edit
section: Republic of China \(Taiwan\)")]

See also: [List of medical schools in
Taiwan](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_Taiwan "List of medical schools in
Taiwan")

The medical education in the [Republic of China
(Taiwan)](/wiki/Republic_of_China "Republic of China") is usually 7 years
(6-year learning plus 1-year internship) in duration, starting right after
high schools. The first 2 years in the 7-year system is composed of basic
sciences and liberal art courses. Doctor-patient classes are emphasized, and
most schools require compulsory amounts of volunteer hours. Clinical sciences
are compressed into a two-year program in the 3rd and 4th years. The duration
of clerkships and internships varies from school to school, but all of them
end at the 7th grade. Taiwan's medical education began in 1897 and is over 100
years old now. Students graduate with a Doctor of Medicine (MD) degree.
Starting from the year 2013, incoming students will have a 6+2 year
curriculum, in which the first 6 years are oriented similarly as before and
the last two years are Post Graduate Years; this change aims to increase
primary care capabilities of medical school graduates.[44]

### Saudi
Arabia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=47 "Edit
section: Saudi Arabia")]

See also: [List of medical schools in Saudi
Arabia](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools#Saudi_Arabia "List of medical schools")

In Saudi Arabia medical education is free for all Saudi citizens. A medical
student must pass an entrance examination and complete a 1-year pre-medical
course containing some basic medical subjects including: Biology, Organic
Chemistry, Inorganic Chemistry, Physics, Medical Biostatistics, and English
for medical uses. Passing this year is commonly considered as the most
challenging. It offers an MBBS (Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery)
degree. after one pre-medical course, five medical years and one training
year. By 2010, there are 24 medical schools in KSA- 21 nonprofit and three
private medical schools the last college opened was Sulaiman AlRajhi Colleges
with its partnership with Maastricht in the Netherlands.

### Singapore[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=48
"Edit section: Singapore")]

Currently, there are 3 medical schools in Singapore. 2 of them offers
undergraduate (5 years degree) and the other offers postgraduate (4 years)
entry.

### South
Korea[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=49 "Edit
section: South Korea")]

See also: [List of medical schools in South
Korea](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools#South_Korea "List of medical schools")

Currently, there are 41 medical schools in South Korea.[45] Medical programs
in South Korea used to be direct-entry programs such as in the UK, taking six
years to complete. However, most universities were going through a transition
from direct-entry to a 4+4 year system, such as those found in the United
States and Canada.[46] Recently, about half of the universities are converting
back to six years direct-entry program by 2015, and almost all of the
universities are converting it back by 2017.

### Sri Lanka[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=50
"Edit section: Sri Lanka")]

See also: [List of medical schools in Sri
Lanka](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools#Sri_Lanka "List of medical schools")

There are eight medical schools in Sri Lanka that teach evidence based
(sometimes called "western") medicine. The oldest medical school is the
[Faculty of Medicine, University of
Colombo](/wiki/Faculty_of_Medicine,_University_of_Colombo "Faculty of
Medicine, University of Colombo"), established as Ceylon Medical School in
1870. There are medical faculties in Peradeniya, Kelaniya, Sri
Jayawardanepura, Galle, Batticaloa, Jaffna and Rajarata as well.

Kelaniya Medical Faculty initially started as the [North Colombo Medical
College](/wiki/North_Colombo_Medical_College "North Colombo Medical College")
(NCMC), a private medical institution. It was one of the earliest private
higher educational institutions (1980). Heavy resistance by the medical
professionals, university students and other professionals led to its
nationalization and to its renaming as the Kelaniya Medical Faculty.

Faculty of Health-Care Sciences is the faculty that offers MBBS together with
other para-medical courses. It is an entity of the Eastern University - Sri
Lanka.

The Open International University for Complementary Medicines(OIUCM),
established under World Health Organization teaches various field of Medicines
and related program of Environmental Sciences.

[47] [48] despite having basic problems of training programme.

[Postgraduate Institute of Medicine](/wiki/Postgraduate_Institute_of_Medicine
"Postgraduate Institute of Medicine") (PGIM) is the only institution that
provides specialist training of medical doctors.

The [Institute of Indigenous Medicine](/wiki/Institute_of_Indigenous_Medicine
"Institute of Indigenous Medicine") of the [University of
Colombo](/wiki/University_of_Colombo "University of Colombo"), the Gampaha
Wickramarachchi Ayurvedhic Medicine Institute of the [University of
Kelaniya](/wiki/University_of_Kelaniya "University of Kelaniya") and the
Faculty of Siddha Medicine, [University of Jaffna](/wiki/University_of_Jaffna
"University of Jaffna") teach [Ayurvedha](/wiki/Ayurvedha "Ayurvedha")/
[Unani](/wiki/Unani "Unani") / [Siddha](/wiki/Siddha "Siddha") Medicine.

### Thailand[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=51
"Edit section: Thailand")]

See also: [List of medical schools in
Thailand](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools_in_Thailand "List of medical schools
in Thailand")

The first medical school in Thailand was established back in 1890 at [Siriraj
Hospital](/wiki/Siriraj_Hospital "Siriraj Hospital"), which is now become
[Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital, Mahidol
University](/wiki/Faculty_of_Medicine_Siriraj_Hospital,_Mahidol_University
"Faculty of Medicine Siriraj Hospital, Mahidol University"). Currently, there
are 26[49][_[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")_]
medical programs offered nationwide. Most of the Thai medical schools are
government-funded and require Thai citizenship for eligibility. Two private
medical schools exist at the moment. Some Thais choose to attend private
medical schools or attend a medical school in a foreign country due to
relatively few openings and extremely competitive entrance examination scores
required for enrollment in public medical schools.

The Thai medical education is a six-year system, consisting of 1 year in
basic-science, 2 years in pre-clinical training, and 3 years for clinical
training. Upon graduation, all medical students must pass national medical
licensing examinations and a university-based comprehensive test. After
medical school, newly graduated doctors are under contract to spend a year of
internship and 2 years of tenure in rural areas before they are eligible for
any other residency positions or specialized training, mostly in locations
outside [Bangkok](/wiki/Bangkok "Bangkok").

Students will receive [Doctor of Medicine](/wiki/Doctor_of_Medicine "Doctor of
Medicine") (MD) degree at the end of the process. This degree is equivalent to
a [master's degree](/wiki/Master%27s_degree "Master's degree") in Thailand.

### Albania[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Medical_school&action=edit&section=53
"Edit section: Albania")]

See also: [List of medical schools in
Albania](/wiki/List_of_medical_schools#Albania "List of medical schools")

There are four Medical Schools (Fakultete te Mjeksise) in Albania:

  * [University of Tirana](/wiki/University_of_Tirana "University of Tirana") Faculty of Medicine
  * [Kristal University](/wiki/Kristal_University "Kristal University") Faculty of Medicine
  * [WORLDWIDE University](/w/index.php?title=WORLDWIDE_University&action=edit&redlink=1 "WORLDWIDE University \(page does not exist\)") Faculty of Medicine
  * [Zonja e Keshillit te Mire](/w/index.php?title=Zonja_e_Keshillit_te_Mire&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zonja e Keshillit te Mire \(page does not exist\)")

These medical schools are usually affiliated with regional hospitals. The
course of study lasts 6 years. Students are conferred degree Doctor of
Medicine (M.D.) upon graduation.

"Edit section: Austria")]

  * [Medical University of Vienna](/wiki/Medical_University_of_Vienna "Medical University of Vienna")
  * [Sigmund Freud University Vienna](/wiki/Sigmund_Freud_University_Vienna "Sigmund Freud University Vienna"), Medical School
  * [Medical University of Graz](/wiki/Medical_University_of_Graz "Medical University of Graz")
  * [Medical University of Innsbruck](/wiki/Medical_University_of_Innsbruck "Medical University of Innsbruck")
